Lesson 5: Verbs haben, sein & Modal Verbs

In this lesson, we learn 3 important things: the verbs haben (to have), sein (to be), and modal verbs like 'can', 'should', 'want to'.

💡 What does haben mean?

haben means to have. Just like we did in Lesson 1, we will now conjugate it:

  • ich habe – I have
  • du hast – you have
  • er hat – he has
  • wir haben – we have
  • sie haben – they have

✅ Examples with haben:

  • Ich habe Pizza – I have pizza
  • Du hast Pasta – You have pasta
  • Er hat Brot – He has bread

🧠 What does sein mean?

sein means to be. We conjugate it in a similar pattern as before:

  • ich bin – I am
  • du bist – you are
  • er ist – he is
  • wir sind – we are
  • sie sind – they are

✅ Examples with sein:

  • Ich bin Rahul – I am Rahul
  • Du bist Studentin – You are a student (female)
  • sie sind ein Mannschaft – They are a team

Easy, isn't it? These 5 pronouns always follow a similar pattern — and once you remember this, it gives you a strong base in German speaking.

🛠️ What are Modal Verbs?

Modal verbs are helping verbs. In English, we use can, may, should, will, want to etc. to help the main verb.

For example: We can play cricket

Can is the modal verb, and play is the main verb.

In German, only one verb (the modal) changes form. The second verb stays in its original infinitive form and moves to the end of the sentence.


We can play cricket = Wir können Cricket spielen

  • können is the modal verb
  • spielen is the infinitive 'to play'

Let’s try another one:

I can play cricket = Ich kann Cricket spielen

  • können becomes kann because it follows ich
  • spielen goes to the end and stays unchanged

✅ Only one verb changes — the other stays in the infinitive!

🎉 Well done! You now understand how to use haben, sein, and modal verbs. Try to write 3–4 sentences using them — we will practice in exercises next.
